0	http://reuters.com/article/us-pennsylvania-budget-idUSKCN0ZR07N	Pennsylvania Governor Wolf says spending plan to become law	"
Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf said late on Sunday a bill to increase funding in the state will become law
column2: about 24 hours before the 10-day period for him to veto the blueprint runs out.Pennsylvania lawmakers passed the $31.6 billion spending plan on Thursday
column3: a day before the deadline for the start of fiscal 2017.

column1: The state will still not have a complete revenue plan to pay for the increased spending
column2: so the legislature will have to keep working on the same.

column1: (Reporting by Hilary Russ in New York and Ismail Shakil in Bengaluru; Editing by Gopakumar Warrier)"

column2: saying that hackers had targeted the White House.""I am concerned about it
column3: I don't think we have it perfect. We have to do better
column4: we have to learn from mistakes

2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-flynn-idUSKCN0ZQ0RB	Possible Trump VP pick says he supports abortion rights	"
By James Oliphant
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn
column2: under consideration by Republican Donald Trump as a possible vice presidential choice
column3: said on Sunday he favors a woman's right to choose whether to have an abortion.That stance places Flynn
column4: the former head of the Defense Intelligence Agency
column5: at odds with the official Republican Party position
column6: which is firmly anti-abortion.Asked about his position on abortion on ABC News' ""This Week
column9: said ""women have to be able to choose"" and that women ""have to make the decision because they're the ... ones that are going to decide to bring up that child or not."" Trump
column10: the presumptive Republican White House nominee
column11: has said he will pick his vice president before the party's nomination convention opens on July 18. Flynn has been an adviser to the Trump campaign since early this year.

column1: The Washington Post reported on Saturday that Trump is becoming increasingly infatuated with Flynn
column2: who ran the Defense Intelligence Agency from 2012-2014 under President Barack Obama
column3: because he believes national unrest and the threat of terrorism may demand a ""tough and steady"" presence on the ticket. As a businessman and real-estate developer
column4: Trump also likes the idea of teaming up with another non-politician
column5: the Post reported.

column1: For weeks Trump has conducted a high-profile canvassing of Republican political stalwarts as part of his running mate search
column2: but he has also made clear he is looking at what a military leader would bring to the ticket.A source familiar with the matter confirmed to Reuters on Saturday that Flynn had emerged as a possibility.

column1: According to the source
column2: Flynn is seen as someone who would be able to help Trump in the area of national security at a time of challenges abroad like the threat from Islamic State militants.Trump is also considering more conventional vice presidential contenders
column3: such as former House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich
column4: Indiana Governor Mike Pence or New Jersey Governor Chris Christie. (Reporting by James Oliphant; Editing by Caren Bohan)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-police-obama-police-idUSKCN0ZQ0MB	Obama says attacks on police hurt Black Lives Matter cause	"
MADRID U.S. President Barack Obama has warned that attacks on police over racial bias would hurt the anti-racism Black Lives Matter movement
column2: days after a sniper killed five police officers in Dallas in apparent revenge for police shootings of black people. Obama said although most activists from the Black Lives Matter movement wanted to see better relations between communities and law enforcement
column3: violence and overly broad criticism against police undermined the protest movement.""I want to say to say to everyone concerned about ... racial bias in the criminal justice system that maintaining a truthful
column4: serious and respectful tone is going to help mobilize American society to bring about real change
column5: Obama said.""Whenever those of us who are concerned about failures of the criminal justice system attack police
column6: you are doing a disservice to the cause
column7: he told a news conference in Madrid where he is on a one-day visit.

column1: Micah Johnson
column2: a black U.S. military veteran of the Afghan war
column3: opened fire on police officers on Thursday during a protest in Dallas against the fatal shootings of two black men by police in Louisiana and Minnesota the previous day.Johnson wanted to ""kill white people
column4: especially white officers
column5: Dallas Police Chief David Brown said after the attack on Thursday night.

column1: The Black Lives Matter group said on Friday it advocated dignity
column2: not murder
column3: in response to the shooting that also left seven other police officers and two civilians wounded.Obama said there was legitimate criticism to be made of the criminal justice system and that citizens should continue to protest against it.

column1: I would hope that police organizations are also respectful of the frustrations that people in these communities feel and not just dismiss these protests as political correctness or politics or attacks on police
column2: he said. (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe; Writing by Angus Berwick; Editing by Raissa Kasolowsky)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-vicepresident-idUSKCN0ZP0SI	Trump looks at retired general Flynn as possible running mate	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump is giving consideration to retired Lieutenant General Michael Flynn as a potential vice presidential running mate
column2: a Republican source familiar with the process said on Saturday.For weeks Trump has conducted a high-profile canvassing of Republican political stalwarts as part of his running mate search
column3: but he has also made clear he is looking at what a military leader would bring to the ticket.The source
column4: speaking on condition of anonymity
column5: said Flynn has emerged as a possibility
column6: confirming reports in the New York Post and The Washington Post. The Trump campaign had no comment.The thinking is that Flynn
column7: who has been a foreign policy adviser to Trump
column8: would be able to help Trump in the area of national security at a time of challenges abroad like the threat from Islamic State militants.

column1: Trump is also considering a more conventional political choice for his running mate
column2: such as former House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich
column3: Indiana Governor Mike Pence or New Jersey Governor Chris Christie.Flynn was chief of the Defense Intelligence Agency under President Barack Obama from 2012-2014.

column1: He has spoken in the past about wanting the United States to work more closely with Russia to resolve global security issues.Flynn told Russia Today in an interview published on Dec. 10 that the United States and Russia should work together to resolve the Syrian civil war and defeat Islamic State.
Flynn has a book coming out next week
column2: co-written with Michael Ledeen
column3: titled: ""The Field of Fight: How We Can Win the Global War Against Radical Islam and Its Allies."" (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Leslie Adler)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN0ZP0MJ	Sanders' TPP stance shot down by Democrats' platform committee	"
By Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A trade deal fight led by U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders on Saturday failed to fully materialize as rival and presumptive nominee Hillary Clinton announced a compromise to expand mandatory healthcare funding over the next decade.At a meeting of the Democratic Party draft platform committee in Orlando
column2: Florida
column3: on Saturday
column4: supporters of Sanders were unable to influence the committee to adopt strong language opposing the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact
column5: marking a powerful blow to the efforts by the U.S. senator from Vermont to push the party further to the left.""We did everything we could to win that vote
column6: said Sanders policy adviser Warren Gunnels. ""It was very disappointing.""Instead of a condemnation specific to the TPP
column7: the committee reached language saying they would oppose ""trade agreements that do not support good American jobs.""Sanders has headed the effort on the U.S. left to oppose the TPP and trade deals like it
column8: which he says are unfair to American workers. Clinton has also come out as opposed to the agreement. Despite Clinton having already secured the requisite delegates to clinch the party's nomination at the July 25-28 convention
column9: Sanders remains in the race to be the party's nominee.

column1: He has indicated that he would hold off on endorsing Clinton for the Nov. 8 general election fight against Republican presumptive nominee Donald Trump until she adopted policies and campaign language that more closely resembled his own more liberal tone.""I would like to say that while this vote was disappointing
column2: we have won some tremendous victories
column3: Gunnels said
column4: including securing language in the draft supporting a federal $15 minimum wage
column5: another trademark issue for Sanders.On the same day
column6: the Clinton campaign announced changes to its healthcare policy proposal
column7: including increasing mandatory healthcare funding under the Affordable Care Act by $40 billion over the next 10 years
column8: highlighting the significant influence Sanders still yields over the party. ""We have more work to do to finish our long fight to provide universal
column10: affordable healthcare to everyone in America
column11: Clinton said in a statement that included her intention to give Americans the choice of a public-option insurance plan and allow for individuals below Medicare age
column13: to opt in to the U.S. federal program that pays elderly Americans' hospital bills.

column1: Sanders has made combating healthcare costs a rallying cry of his campaign and often battled with Clinton during the primary race on how best to reach their shared goal of universal healthcare.On Saturday
column2: Sanders praised the updates to Clinton's proposal as a step in the right direction to ""save lives and ease suffering
column3: indicating
column4: along with the more liberal tone in several parts of the 2016 platform draft
column5: a growing compromise between the two camps.For Clinton
column6: an endorsement from Sanders - seen as a champion of the progressive left - could open the door to many of his supporters who have been reluctant to support the more moderate Clinton.

column1: The proposal brought forth today by Secretary Clinton
column2: working with our campaign
column3: is an important step forward in expanding healthcare in America - and expanding health insurance and healthcare access to tens of millions of Americans
column4: he said in a statement.""I congratulate Secretary Clinton for this extremely important initiative.""The New York Times reported on Thursday that an endorsement is imminent
column5: and Sanders is expected to officially throw his support behind Clinton
column6: a former U.S. secretary of state
column7: at a campaign stop in New Hampshire early next week.(This story corrects age at which individuals could opt in to Medicare under Clinton plan in paragraph 10) (Reporting by Alana Wise; editing by Leslie Adler

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-police-obama-idUSKCN0ZP0O6	U.S. gun rules heighten tension between police
column2: citizens: Obama	"

column1: By Ayesha Rascoe
| WARSAW
WARSAW President Barack Obama pledged on Saturday to seek ways to calm racial tensions and reduce divisions between police and minorities during his final months in office
column2: but he warned that easy access to guns nationwide exacerbated the problem.Obama spoke at the end of a week in which five policemen were killed by a sniper in Dallas and two black men were killed by police in Minnesota and Louisiana. He said he would bring together civil rights and law enforcement leaders for talks at the White House next week after returning from a trip to Europe.Obama
column3: the first black U.S. president
column4: has spoken out on racial issues throughout his time in the White House. He has also tried but failed to reform American gun laws
column5: stymied by Republicans in Congress who have opposed any measures that they seen as impinging on the Constitutional right to bear arms
column6: despite a series of mass shootings in recent years.Obama said the Dallas police force reduced murder rates and community complaints by taking the issue of race and police conduct seriously
column7: and said he hoped that would inspire ""constructive actions"" in the coming weeks.""That's the spirit that we all need to embrace. That's the spirit that I want to build on
column8: he said during a press conference in Poland.But the divisive issue of gun control could not be separated from the tension between police and local citizens

column1: Obama noted that Dallas police on Thursday had to protect themselves and citizens from sniper fire while deciphering who had guns among those taking part in a protest decrying police shootings of black men.The presence of a gun in the car where Philando Castile
column3: was killed by police in Minnesota on Wednesday contributed to that event
column4: he said.""In Minneapolis
column5: we don't know yet what happened
column6: but we do know that there was a gun in the car that apparently was licensed

column1: We can't just ignore that and pretend that that's somehow political ... it is a contributing factor - not the sole factor - but a contributing factor to the broader tensions that arise between police and the communities where they serve.""Obama is very unlikely to succeed in reviving major gun control reform before he leaves office in January.Lawmakers in Congress have fought over three rival gun measures since the June 12 mass shootings at a gay nightclub in Orlando. Democrats promised to put pressure on Republicans next week to win votes for measures to expand background checks and allow the Justice Department to block gun sales to people on government watch lists.

Obama said on Saturday he hoped his legacy on the issue of race would be one of urging Americans to listen to each other and understand the country's difficult relationship with race.""The legacy of slavery and Jim Crow and discrimination didn't suddenly vanish with the passage of the Civil Rights Act or the Voting Rights Act or the election of Barack Obama
column2: he said.He said he hoped his words as president had conveyed ""that things have gotten better
column3: substantially better
column4: but that we've still got a lot more work to do."" (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe in Warsaw; Additional reporting by Jeff Mason and Arshad Mohammed in Washington; Writing by Jeff Mason; Editing by Leslie Adler)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obama-clinton-idUSKCN0ZP0QV	Obama 'concerned' about U.S. State Department handling of classified information	"

WARSAW U.S. President Barack Obama said on Saturday he was concerned about how the State Department handles classified information but cast this as part of a government-wide challenge in the age of email
column2: texts and smartphones.FBI Director James Comey on Tuesday recommended against prosecuting Hillary Clinton or her aides for their ""extremely careless"" handling of classified information on the private email server that she used as secretary of state.Comey said the FBI had found evidence that ""the security culture of the State Department in general
column3: and with respect to use of unclassified systems in particular
column4: was generally lacking in the kind of care for classified information that's found elsewhere in the U.S. government.""

column1: Asked about the FBI director's assessment
column2: Obama told reporters in a news conference: ""I am concerned.""""The advent of email and texts and smart phones is just generating enormous amounts of data
column3: Obama added
column4: saying that this
column5: in turn was ""putting enormous pressure on the department to sort through it

column1: Obama said that if one classified too much
column2: the benefits of the information evaporated because it took too long to process. ""It reflects a larger problem in government
column3: he added. Clinton has said her use of a private email server was a mistake.

column1: (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe
column2: Jeff Mason and Arshad Mohammed; Editing by G Crosse and Sandra Maler)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-security-idUSKCN0ZP0QN	Republican Party chairman confident in Cleveland convention security	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican Party chief Reince Priebus expressed confidence on Saturday that security will be able to handle any protests at the party's convention later this month in Cleveland
column2: where Donald Trump is to be nominated as the Republican presidential candidate.Priebus
column3: chairman of the Republican National Committee
column4: told Reuters in a telephone interview that the tragic shootings in Texas
column5: Minnesota and Louisiana in recent days may lead to a more peaceful discourse in general across the country.Cleveland police on Friday tightened their security plan for the July 18-21 Republican National Convention in the wake of the shootings. They also increased surveillance and intelligence operations.The outpouring of grief among Americans after the bloodshed could lead to a ""more understanding and polite discourse and a feeling of support in communities and with police
column7: and that this same feeling of understanding could also take place in Cleveland.

column1: We've been working really hard on security. I'm very confident that things are going to go very well in Cleveland. The police are there in full force to be helpful to protesters
column2: but also to keep the event safe and free from incident
column3: he said.Priebus
column4: who has worked to rally Republicans behind Trump
column5: said the convention should serve as a vehicle to unify more party loyalists behind the New York businessman whose incendiary rhetoric and policy positions have troubled some Republicans.Priebus added that the ""never Trump"" movement has ebbed and that he did not believe any rebellion among Republican delegates at the convention against Trump would succeed.

column1: It's one thing to be unhappy because your person didn't win. I get that part. But it's another step to now say because I don't like the way this is going
column2: I'm going to take something away from someone who won it fair and square. There's just not a lot of people that are willing to do that
column3: he said.Priebus
column4: who has privately counseled Trump
column5: said it is important for him to continue making the case against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton after the FBI concluded she had been ""extremely careless"" in handling some sensitive emails as President Barack Obama's secretary of state.

column1: Trump
column2: at a campaign rally in Ohio on Wednesday
column3: had sharply criticized Clinton at the outset
column4: but then diverted to attacking the news media for how it is covering his campaign.""In a 45-minute rally
column5: he spent a long time on Hillary and I think it's OK for him to divert here and there
column6: but I do think focusing on Hillary is important and a vision for America is important

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-airshow-britain-lockheed-fighter-idUSKCN0ZP0QA	Pentagon says near deal with Lockheed for more F-35 fighter jets	"
By Andrea Shalal
| RAF FAIRFORD
column2: England

column1: RAF FAIRFORD
column2: England The U.S. Department of Defense and Lockheed Martin Corp are in the final stages of negotiations about two contracts for 160 fighter jets
column3: tandem deals valued at more than $14 billion
column4: the Pentagon's F-35 program manager said on Saturday.""We're in the end game
column5: Air Force Lieutenant General Chris Bogdan said in an interview at the Royal International Air Tattoo the world's largest military airshow
column6: where six F-35 Lightning II jets are flying this week.Bogdan said an agreement could be finalised soon
column7: but declined to predict if it could be announced at the Farnborough International Airshow next week. He said all the major issues had been resolved and the fate of the deal was largely in Lockheed's hands at the moment.Lockheed's F-35 program manager Jeff Babione had told reporters on Thursday that he expected to reach an agreement soon about contracts for the ninth and 10th production contracts for the new warplane.

column1: Sources familiar with the two contracts said they would likely be valued between $14 billion and $15 billion.Babione said the price of the F-35A conventional takeoff and landing version of the jet would drop to under $100 million per plane in the 10th low-rate production batch
column2: including an engine built by Pratt & Whitney
column3: a unit of United Technologies Corp.Bogdan said he was continuing to work on a block buy deal for international partners on the $379 billion warplane project
column4: the largest arms program in the world
column5: as part of a larger effort to drive down the jets' cost.

column1: Buying larger numbers of jets at a time -- starting with the 12th production batch of jets -- could generate savings of $2 billion to $2.8 billion
column2: even if the U.S. military was not able to join in until it got congressional approval
column3: he said. The U.S. military services would likely join in starting with the 13th and 14th production lots
column4: which would reduce the initially anticipated savings by ""hundreds of millions of dollars
column5: he said.

column1: Bogdan told reporters the program office was carefully assessing any potential impact on trade and tariffs stemming from Britain's vote to leave the European Union
column2: but the initial expectation was that it would not have much impact.A drop in the value of the British pound could help lower some costs
column3: since 15 percent of the jet is built by UK firms.            (Editing by Louise Heavens)"
